title: Thursday, 17th August, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM11:01am

Morning

PM11:01am

So which is he?

PM11:01am

Reality TV genius or gobshite?

11:01 am
PM11:02am

https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump/status/897799882802704385

PM11:02am

I know everyone will say 'both'

PM11:02am

Feels as though it's all coming to a head with the un-American President

11:03 am
PM11:03am

Though Levine was terrific on all this

PM11:03am

As per usual

PM11:03am

Speaking of business leaders who have loaned their credibility to Trump, what's Gary Cohn up to? Cohn is the chairman of Trump's National Economic Council, a key White House aide, and a potential nominee to be the next chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. He "stood by uncomfortably" yesterday while Trump defended white supremacists. Here is a fairly hilarious endorsement of Cohn from William Dudley, who called Cohn a "reasonable candidate" to run the Fed. It's true! Cohn is not a traditional candidate to be the chairman of the Fed, or even a good candidate necessarily, but he is a reasonable candidate. He's not an economist, but he's sort of economist-shaped. You could imagine him saying economics-y things. In the Trump era, a "reasonable candidate" is about the best you can expect. Cohn would definitely be a better choice to run the Fed than Barron Trump, or David Duke. Here is where I would normally say "I hope that maybe getting to run the Fed is worth putting up with all the white supremacism," but I don't really. I hope he's ashamed.

11:03 am
PM11:03am

Withering

BE11:04am

He'll jump before he's pushed, of course, meaning we don't get the catharsis of impeachment proceedings.

PM11:04am

Yeah, maybe

11:04 am
BE11:04am

Paddy Power is 2/1 on impeachment this year, 11/2 on next.

BE11:04am

http://www.paddypo...oc_grp_ids=2944322

BE11:04am

11:04 am

PM11:04am

PM11:05am

Not sure we've made enough of that this morning

11:05 am
PM11:05am

PM11:05am

But fascinating all the same

BE11:05am

(@AM: yes.)

11:05 am
PM11:05am

Anyway, let's have a proper pic for today

11:06 am
PM11:06am

With Learndirect

BE11:07am

Links?

11:07 am
PM11:07am

https://www.ft.com/search?q=learndirect

BE11:07am

To stocks!

undefined
PM11:08am

Fed divided, etc

PM11:08am

Everyone's a bit wobbly

11:08 am
PM11:08am

Well, everyone who's not on holiday

BE11:08am

(@Nately: the Dunning-Kruger Effect is the syndrome of our time.)

BE11:09am

Yeah, it's mostly ex-divs to be fair.

11:08 am
PM11:09am

Ah, of course

BE11:09am

There isn't that much happening aside from those.

BE11:10am

Imperial, BATS, Merlin, Pearson (though to be fair, the latter is rather less a dividend effect than investors were expecting this time last year).

11:10 am
PM11:10am

hehe

BE11:11am

Other wise, we have Kingfisher still being Kingfisher.

Kingfisher PLC (KGF:LSE): Last: 290.90, down 16.5 (-5.37%), High: 301.20, Low: 289.20, Volume: 10.39m
11:11 am
PM11:11am

https://www.invest...1708170700032117O/

PM11:11am

Q2 there

BE11:11am

With a warning that its restructuring programme's messing things up.

11:11 am
BE11:11am

There had been a lot of advance warning of this.

PM11:12am

Most of the numbers are in brackets

BE11:12am

Yeah, see the slew of comments in the middle of last month about how the five-year plan was probably going to be toast, having failed on year one.

11:12 am
BE11:12am

Here, for instance: https://www.ft.com...-9a66-93fb352ba1fe

BE11:14am

Today, we get confirmation both that trading at B&Q and in France is getting worse, we get lowered targets on the neverending transformation programme.

BE11:14am

Have Investec to summarise the numbers.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

The market was pre-warned to expect the sales disruption from the implementation of ‘ONE’ Kingfisher seen in Q1 to continue in Q2. Trends were similar with a weak French/B&Q performance more than offsetting a good Screwfix/Polish performance. We have nudged down FY18/FY19e PBT forecasts by c.1%. We retain our Sell. While valuation is not demanding, short-term risk of further downgrades remains high given scale/complexity of transformation.

BE11:14am

Trends in Q2 similar to Q1 with a weak French and B&Q performance. Reported Q2 LFL for main divisions – B&Q -4.7% (INVe flat; Q1 +0.5%); Screwfix +10.8% (INVe +10%; Q1 +12.6%); Castorama -2.8% (INVe -4%; Q1 -4.3%); Brico Depot -5.1% (INVe -6%; Q1 -6.8%); and Poland +4% (INVe +3%; Q1 +3.5%).
Sales continue to be impacted by c.2% (similar to Q1) from out-of-stocks/poor availability caused by unforeseen supply chain disruption from ‘unifying’ its product ranges programme.
Sequential deterioration in B&Q performance qoq a focus, but this is due to a shift in seasonal sales between 2 quarters relative to last year rather than a deterioration in underlying sales. Non-seasonal Q2 LFL sales -1.6% improved on Q1 -3.9%, and note UK LFL continues to benefit by just over 1% from sales transfer from the store closures last year.
Management comfortable with consensus FY18 underlying EPS 26p (adj. EPS 21.1p incl. transformation costs) despite increasing GNFR (goods not for resale) savings guidance to £25m (prev £20m) and EUR/GBP FX moving in its favour. We nudge normalised FY18e/FY19e PBT incl. transformation costs down 1%, with lower sales assumptions offsetting cost savings and currency.
Valuation (CY18e PE 12.2x) is not cheap enough, in our view, given execution risk from ‘One Kingfisher’ and that the inflection point/visibility on whether it will work is likely to be FY19/FY20. While there is little in the valuation for delivery of the £500m cost savings target, we believe there is a high risk of further downgrades in the short term and see better investment opportunities elsewhere.

PM11:14am

they're sellers, yeah?

11:14 am
BE11:14am

They are.

PM11:15am

As are UBS I see -- you noted the downgrade last month

PM11:15am

They have one of those short Q&As you love

11:15 am
PM11:16am

Q: How did the results compare vs expectations?
A: Group sales were up 4% to £3,148m (UBSe £3,146m) with LFL -1.9% v consensus -0.8%. UK sales were down -2% to £1,332m with B&Q LFL -4.7% (UBSe -4%) and Screwfix +10.8% (UBSe +10%). France sales were up 5% in Sterling to £1,188m (down -3.3% in local FX) with LFL –3.8%, an improvement from the -5.5% in Q1. International sales were up 17% to £628m with flat LFL (UBSe +1.4%).
Q: What were the most noteworthy areas in the results?
A: The supply chain disruption seen in Q1 continued in Q2 but is on an improving trend. B&Q LFL sales slowed on a weaker consumer (non-seasonal sales -1.6%) and a negative weather impact (seasonal sales down 11% at B&Q and -6% at Castorama).
Q: Has the company's outlook/guidance changed?
A: After some increased cost mitigation, the company says it is happy with 26p FY18 consensus (UBSe 25.3p) although this may now include the benefit of a stronger EUR.
Q: How would we expect investors to react?
A: Sentiment has been negative, but tough trading conditions likely to weigh on shares.

PM11:16am

They are certainly efficient -- the Q&As

BE11:16am

I like for that reason.

11:16 am
BE11:16am

Meanwhile, Geoff at Morgan Stanley sticks with his idea (as referenced in the link above) that Kingfisher will eventually reach the point of abandoning he plan.

BE11:17am

Which'll be positive, as it's likely to break the company apart.

BE11:18am

- The LfL growth in the UK looks weak (UK & Ireland LFL has come in at -1.0% for FYQ2 versus consensus of +1.5%). The miss on market expectations is driven by weak performance in B&Q UK & Ireland with LFL for FYQ2 coming in at -4.7% (we had not seen consensus expectations for B&Q, however we estimated LFL of +1.0%). The company is citing a strong comparative from last year due to the weather. Trading at Screwfix remains healthy with LFL for FYQ2 being reported at +10.8%.
- We also think it interesting to highlight that total sales growth for the UK & Ireland (i.e. B&Q and Screwfix) is significantly less than that reported at Travis Perkins in the Consumer division in FYH1 (Wickes and Toolstation). In the Consumer division Travis Perkins reported +7.3% total sales growth for FYH1, whereas Kingfisher has reported -0.3% for the half year.
- Sales in France remain very subdued but not much worse than market expectations (France LFL for FYQ2 is -3.8% versus consensus of -3.5%). Within France Castorama LfL is down -2.8% and Brico Depot is down -5.1% in FYQ2.
- As anticipated this is a fairly brief statement, so there isn't much 'n ew news' here on the 'One Kingfisher' strategy. We expect more detail on this at the Interims next month. Management states that there is "continued business disruption from our ONE Kingfisher plan albeit with an overall improving trend".
- We have yet to speak to the company this morning but the statement makes clear that the company is comfortable with underlying EPS consensus expectations for FY2017/18. Therefore we do not expect much change in consensus forecasts today. Prior to today consensus was looking for Pre Tax Profits in FY 2017/18e of £667m (giving EPS of 22p).
- Based on last night's closing price and existing consensus forecasts, Kingfisher is trading on 11.8x calendarised 2018 earnings, 6.0x EBITDA with a 3.7% dividend yield. This compares with a UK General Retail sector trading on 12.1x, 7.6x and 4.4% respectively.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

The caveat on the MOST call was always that management could stay irrational for longer than you could stay solvent, to repurpose an old quote.

undefined
BE11:19am

Actually, since we're on the subject of non-food retail ......

11:19 am
BE11:19am

.... and apropos nothing much ......

PM11:19am

Go on

BE11:20am

There were some curious happenings in B&M while we were on summer break.

11:20 am
PM11:20am

oh yeah?

B&M European Value Retail SA (BME:LSE): Last: 377.40, no change, High: 377.80, Low: 374.90, Volume: 235.88k
BE11:21am

You'll remember shortly before we knocked off that the Sunday Times had a piece suggesting that B&M might be a takeover target for Asda.

11:21 am
BE11:21am

Quoted a price of £4.4bn, which'd only be 18% above the current market cap.

PM11:21am

Yes do remember

BE11:22am

And the steers we were getting post that report was that Asda, if it had ever been properly interested, now isn't.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

And then, a week or so later, B&M bought Heron Food.

BE11:22am

A limited assortment, discount convenience chain with 250 or so stores.

BE11:22am

That was a bit weird. B&M was widely expected to make acquisitions, but folk thought it was more likely to buy overseas non-food than domestic food.

11:22 am
BE11:23am

What's often missed about B&M is that it already had 45% exposure to (branded) food, so the Heron acquisition makes it look even more like an Aldi-ish discount grocer as well as a discount hardlines retailer.

BE11:23am

You'll also remember that B&M owns Jawoll Handels, one of the bigger discount non-food retailers in Germany, which provides 7% of group sales.

BE11:24am

All of which throws up an interesting question: if Asda/Wal-Mart isn't keen on B&M (and we're fairly sure it isn't because it doesn't really make sense as an asset), who would?

11:23 am
BE11:24am

It's all a wee bit tricky, because aside from Action (owned by 3i) there are no real peers for B&M.

BE11:24am

In terms of potential interest you're probably looking at the German retail sector -- though it is full of privately owned companies, on which we have very poor visibility.

BE11:24am

The only one we know about is Metro -- which is now a twin-headed consolidation vehicle having just done a rather complicated breakup into food wholesale and electricals.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

Remember also that Simon Arora, the CEO, still has 21 per cent stake tied up in the family investment vehicle.

PM11:24am

Does B&M actually want to be in play?

BE11:25am

That's a very good question. You're thinking of a 40% premium or thereabouts before Arora would sell, maybe? It all looks a bit unlikely.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

However ...... The Sunday Times story seems to have come from somewhere.

BE11:25am

And if I were to speculate, it's more likely to have come from Düsseldorf than Bentonville, Arkansas.

PM11:25am

hmm

11:25 am
BE11:26am

That's all an aside though. Just talking aloud really.

undefined
PM11:26am

Was just reading about Heron Foods

11:26 am
PM11:26am

It was founded in Hull

PM11:26am

Hull discounter

BE11:26am

Yep.

11:26 am
PM11:26am

Can you think of anything more depressing.

PM11:26am

Buying food at a discount grocer in Hull

BE11:27am

It's kinda the reverse of a discounter. It's the £1.50 for a can of beans market. Necessity rather than choice, average spend per customer sub £5.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

Which is a pretty good market to be in if you're a wholesaler, as demonstrated by Booker.

BE11:28am

What B&M does with it is another question.

BE11:28am

Anyway.

11:27 am
PM11:28am

(Residual -- indeed)

undefined
PM11:01am

Welcome to Markets Live

11:28 am
BE11:28am

(@AAAA: half of it is, yes. The other half's still Metro.)

PM11:28am

UBS has launched a UK takeaway spend tracker,

BE11:28am

Hooray!

11:28 am
PM11:29am

Introducing the UBS Evidence Lab UK spend tracker data

PM11:29am

n the first edition of the UK takeaway spend tracker, we find that Just Eat has the highest consumer loyalty amongst competing brands (at 67%), Deliveroo is a close second (66%) and Domino's is a more distant third at 49%. Just Eat is the favoured brand for 44% (measured in terms of spending), much higher than nearest comp. Domino's at 26%; most importantly JE share has not declined despite the rise of Deliveroo. Deliveroo basket size is declining swiftly (down c8% yoy), indicating that competition could become more intense, but moving down order values is likely a costly move for a three-sided player and we see Just Eat as very well placed to respond

PM11:29am

And as well as doing this little Q&A things that you so love

11:29 am
PM11:29am

They are also ding "our investment thesis in pictures"

PM11:30am

PM11:30am

Thumbs up

11:30 am
PM11:30am

There's 36 pages of this stuff

Just Eat PLC (JE.:LSE): Last: 654.50, up 9.5 (+1.47%), High: 657.00, Low: 647.50, Volume: 1.12m
PM11:31am

Have the Q&A

11:31 am
PM11:31am

Q:Will UK EBITDA margin contract over the next two years?We forecast Just Eat UK EBITDA margins to contract by 60bps in 2018e to 51.8% (vs. 52.4% in 1H17) as delivery investments weigh on gross margins before rebounding to 54% in 2019e as operational leverage plays out and delivery investments plateau at around £15m/annum.moreQ:Will competition from Deliveroo and UberEATS impact Just Eat's order outlook in the next two years?No. Just Eat will likely lose share to new delivery players but in a growing market. Just Eat has a strong brand, loyal customers and the roll out of delivery should enhance its competitive position. We forecast UK order growth CAGR of +15% from 2016-19e, while its market share will likely be eroded at a pace of 1.7pp per year

PM11:32am

We see Just Eat's business model as attractive, with strong network effects, a winner-takes-most market structure and potential for high margins. We forecast Just Eat group revenues to grow +23% from 2016 to 2020e and with the benefits of operational leverage grow EBITDA at +30% CAGR.EVIDENCEUBS Evidence Lab UK consumer spend tracker suggests that Just Eat has high consumer loyalty and has lost limited share to Deliveroo. A UBS Evidence Lab survey of around 800 UK consumers shows that Just Eat outperforms Deliveroo and UberEATS on critical metrics. Our comparative analysis of Grubhub delivery roll-out suggests delivery investments should remain limited for JE. WHAT'S PRICED IN?At a 10% discount to its historical fwd EV/EBITDA multiple, the market seems to be pricing-in UK margin declining to 45% due to higher than expected costs from delivery investments. Partly, it is the lack of clarity around the logistics strategy which weighs on investor sentiment, an issue likely resolved once the new CEO steps in. We believe that the market fears on margin declines are overdone and that scale and rising commission rates will still help push UK margins up to 54% by 2019e.

PM11:32am

That's enough of that.

11:32 am
PM11:33am

Actually you might as well have the forecast chart

PM11:33am

BE11:33am

Well okay, I guess.

11:33 am
BE11:33am

But why in the charts is it bundling in single-brand pizza delivery firms with moped logistics services?

BE11:33am

Just Eat and Deliveroo are middlemen.

BE11:34am

It's like treating Asos and Royal Mail as comparable businesses because they both do the same thing, in the broadest sense.

11:34 am
BE11:34am

Anyway, noted. Ta.

PM11:34am

Well, yes

undefined
11:34 am
BE11:34am

Otherwise in sellside, Bernstein pushing JMAT.

Johnson Matthey PLC (JMAT:LSE): Last: 2,845, up 91 (+3.30%), High: 2,856, Low: 2,794, Volume: 352.38k
BE11:35am

(@AM: I have literally no idea.)

11:35 am
BE11:35am

Familiar story.

BE11:35am

Investors worry too much about diesel going obsolete

BE11:36am

When that's unlikely, at least for a while, because politicians would rather kill the electorate slowly than take away their cars.

11:36 am
BE11:36am

So .. buy for diesel for now, and batteries for later.

BE11:37am

The EU diesel phase-out will be slower and have a smaller impact than investors fear. We have argued the market has overestimated the negative impact; however, JMAT lacked a catalyst. On July 19, we saw the first sign of hope: Elzbieta Bienkowska, the EU Industry Commissioner, wrote to the EC's transport ministers, implying a moderate regulatory approach to the shift away from diesel. Moreover, our new analysis shows some part of the EU diesel catalyst market will persist with better catalysts. Our base case assumes diesel sales (as a % of new) will fall to 38% by 2020 and 25% by 2025. In a "Total dies-aster" scenario in which EU diesel plummets and we erase all light-duty vehicle (LDV) catalysts earnings from our terminal value (i.e., the ICE disappears from all LDVs by the mid-2030s), our valuation would drop to £29/sh.

BE11:37am

Several large longer-term opportunities are being overlooked. (1) LDV and HDD emissions regulations in EMs will boost catalyst demand significantly from 2020, (2) the NMC battery materials business, and (3) process catalysts should pick up beyond 2018.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

Target £36. And 25 pages of working, so hopefully Bernstein won't mind me quoting those two pars from the cover page.

undefined
PM11:39am

This sense that Cohn is about to quit the Trump circus is growing

11:39 am
PM11:39am

Gary D. Cohn, the director of the president’s National Economic Council, who is Jewish, was described by several people close to him as “disgusted” and “deeply upset” by the president’s remarks. But Mr. Cohn has not publicly expressed those views.

PM11:39am

That's the NYT

PM11:39am

https://www.nytime...48421659&te=1&_r=0

11:39 am
PM11:40am

You do have to wonder why he's still there

PM11:40am

Hanging around to get the Fed chair?

PM11:40am

Really?

11:40 am
undefined
PM11:40am

Sorry Bryce, was just distracted by that

PM11:41am

Just such extraordinary news flow

11:41 am
BE11:41am

Yes, well, it's difficult not to spend at least 60% of your day distracted by The Trumpet. In news terms he's like cannon fire.

BE11:41am

We, though, have other stuff.

BE11:42am

Hikma mentioned several times on the right, for instance.

11:41 am
Hikma Pharmaceuticals PLC (HIK:LSE): Last: 1,156, down 172.66 (-12.99%), High: 1,310, Low: 1,101, Volume: 1.72m
PM11:42am

(Lefevre -- nothing fresh since those commets last week)

PM11:42am

Hikma here https://www.invest...1708170700052208O/

11:42 am
BE11:42am

Sales miss. Guidance downgraded.

BE11:43am

And, sorry to do this again, but none of it's unexpected.

BE11:43am

We've had repeated warnings from US pharma about pricing pressure on generics.

11:43 am
BE11:43am

And from India, actually, now I remember.

PM11:43am

So why the market reaction?

PM11:43am

Been smashed

11:44 am
BE11:44am

Good question. I guess Hikma management could've moved a little more explicitly a little earlier .....

BE11:45am

... The warnings from Lupin of India and Cardinal Health gave a fair clue to what was happening.

BE11:45am

But you've also got the injectables business going a bit wrong, which wasn't as easy to predict.

11:45 am
BE11:45am

Here's JP Morgan Caz.

BE11:46am

FY17 LC guidance was cut for Non-Injectables and Injectables, FX headwind slightly increased for branded, overall, guidance downgrade implies consensus downgrades of 2% off the topline, 7% off Adj. EBIT and 9% off Core EPS. Guidance was downgraded for each of Hikma’s three divisions.

BE11:46am

Injectables, the previous topline guidance of $800-825m, was cut 3-6% to $775m, with the 39% Adj. EBIT margin guidance reiterated. This implies $4m lower Adj. EBIT vs. previous guidance, the mid point implying a 1% / $2m downgrade to current consensus forecasts. The downgrade was attributed to challenges in the MENA region (Algeria and GCC), in addition to increased competition in the US. The new FY17 guidance implies sequential H2 vs. H1 growth of $51m/14%, which in light of additional competitive pressure to key products, including glycopyrrolate, could still prove optimistic in our view.

11:46 am
BE11:46am

For Non-Injectables, the previous topline guidance of $670m was cut 8% $50m to $620m. In addition, Adj. EBIT margin guidance was lowered from “slight improvement (on FY16 at 5.8%)” to “around $30m”, implying 4.8% margin, a 1pp downgrade. This guidance downgrade implies an 36% $17m cut to Adj. EBIT vs. the previous guidance, and an 54%/ $24m cut to current consensus forecasts. The downgrade was attributed to “increased competition on pricing and volumes”, and the company “expect tougher conditions to continue in H2”. Partially offsetting the current challenges, in H2 the company see “increased demand for certain products, further portfolio optimisation and a small number of new product launches”. Results included an impairment of $34m on acquired pipeline, i.e Roxane. We note this guidance implies revenue of $315m being a 9% decline yoy H2, which is inline with the expected price impact of 10% yoy. Sequentially this guidance implies 3% growth in H2’17 compared to H1’17.

BE11:47am

Bottom-line: We see today’s release requiring an 9% cut to FY17 consensus EPS, likely similar cuts beyond, assuming the current US generics market headwind are ongoing. Though results will require downgrades, we note the stock is already down 23% since the last guidance cut on May 19th (vs. FSE flat and SXDP -7%), with the stock having taken another leg down following Teva’s guidance downgrade two weeks ago. With short-interest standing at 26% of the free float, we believe a guidance downgrade and further EPS cuts are already anticipated by recent share-price performance. Hence overall we see shares only slightly underperforming today, with the guidance downgrade crystalising existing concerns.

BE11:48am

Note, incidentally, the semi-positive but not unexpected guidance on generic Advair.

11:48 am
BE11:48am

As in, initial discussions with the FDA confirm Hikma's initial assessment that there are no material issues with the substitutability.

BE11:48am

Slight positive for Vectura, though only in the sense that it's not bad news.

Vectura Group PLC (VEC:LSE): Last: 112.85, down 1.15 (-1.00%), High: 116.10, Low: 112.70, Volume: 716.87k
11:48 am
BE11:49am

Back to Hikma though. Here's Barclays.

BE11:49am

The worsening of the US generics market puts even further pressure on the company to execute on high value, differentiated pipeline products of which we believe very little is likely to come in 2017. We anticipate focus on the H1 call will be: i) any update on timing/outcome of FDA discussions on other points, ii) source of pricing pressure i.e. intensification of competition from existing players/buyer consolidation or flurry of new entrants due to increased FDA approvals, and iii) outlook for Injectables beyond FY17 in light of recent launches/approvals of competitor products.

BE11:49am

And Numis.

11:49 am
BE11:50am

Working through the new guidance by division: lower injectables
sales at higher margins, lower generics at lower margins, and branded broadly in line we now derive 98c of Adjusted EPS (from 108c, consensus 106c). This is possibly less bad than feared with some encouraging comments regarding Advair (constructive dialogue with FDA/no material issues) and an expanded strategic partnership with Takeda in MENA offering further evidence of Hikma’s valuable Branded business. No reason to change our FY18 foercasts that had already accounted for increased competition in US injectables and with balance sheet strong (c.1.5x net debt/EBITDA) believe Hikma is well placed to trade through the current uncertainty in US, with 75 products launched in H1 and R&D investment of 7% of sales set to drive a return to stronger growth. Shares trade on 16x downgraded EPS and 9x EV/EBITDA.

BE11:51am

(@BornCynic: it wasn't rejected. It was a complete response letter on an undisclosed major issue in relation to application so approval shifts back a year or so.)

undefined
11:52 am
BE11:53am

Nothing more to say on Estée Lauder, Blue Horseshoe .....

BE11:53am

.... we know the day traders have been all over it for about a week, and have noted previously.

BE11:53am

We also know that Estee has results on .... Friday, I think?

11:54 am
BE11:55am

Which are unlikely to be much of a catalyst. Sales growth fine at the cost of margins, probably.

BE11:55am

And will swing on 2018 guidance. The folks who've been shipping it on board of late are probably not hugely interested in 2018 guidance though, and good luck to them.

undefined
11:57 am
PM11:57am

We've kinda run out of news to discuss

PM11:57am

Fresh news, that is

BE11:58am

Yep. There's not much. Well, I mean, there's a desperate looking attempt to push the Vodafone UK - Liberty story back into the market.

11:58 am
PM11:58am

By who?

BE11:58am

Let's call them "traders" .... Last time we touched on that we ended up debating how many floors Vodafone's HQ has.

BE11:59am

https://www.thereg.../vodafone_liberty/

11:59 am

PM12:00pm

PM12:00pm

Unsurprisingly, inflation came upAs we had anticipated, the Minutes of the July FOMC meeting that were released at 2:00 today, showed some dispersion within the Committee on inflation views, but not a lot; the FOMC is generally of the view that the softness in inflation over past months is transitory. "Most" of the FOMC expected inflation to pick up and "many" said the softness probably reflected idiosyncratic factors. (See: Decoding Fedspeak) There were only a "few" who thought that the framework the FOMC uses for forecasting inflation should be questioned. In their Phillips curve framework, however, there was discussion of possibly lowering their estimate of the natural rate of unemployment; in the June Summary of Economic Projections, the FOMC did just this. Finally, "several" of the FOMC participants share our view that the risks to inflation are skewed to the downside

12:00 pm
PM12:00pm

Labor markets are tight and tighteningThe Minutes reiterated the common theme that labor markets are near or past full employment. "A few" participants expressed concern of overshooting in employment. Overall, however, the FOMC saw the tight and tightening labor market as supportive of their outlook for inflation and their stance for monetary policy

PM12:00pm

Balance sheet timingAlthough the FOMC did not decide to announce balance sheet normalization at the July meeting, "several participants" were prepared to do so. This fact confirms our call that the announcement will happen in September. The Minutes had no further information about the time gap between the announcement of normalization and the implementation of that normalization—that omission will need to be corrected at some point. Finally, the Minutes reiterated the view that once the balance sheet starts to unwind, adjustments to policy will be made through the funds rate, including in response to changes in financial conditions. The normalization of the balance sheet is effectively a done deal, but future hikes will depend on inflation.

PM12:00pm

Financial conditions versus financial stabilityThe FOMC again addressed financial conditions and financial stability. Low long-term interest rates and high stock prices are not, in and of themselves, a problem for the FOMC. Instead, how financial conditions translate into aggregate demand is the key. The FOMC discussed asset valuations, as well. The Committee is clearly paying attention, but generally, they do not see asset prices as signalling a stability risk

12:00 pm
PM12:01pm

Views from strategyWith the Fed still on a normalization path and our view that inflation will resume its rise, the market is likely underpriced in terms of expecting hikes over the medium term. As a result, we retain our call for a flatter 2s10s curve.
